text:
Here are a few steps that may help resolve the issue:

ðŸ”§ Upgrade to SDK 53 (Recommended)
SDK 53 has significantly fewer dependency issues compared to SDK 52.

Run this command in the terminal (code > terminal) to upgrade:

npx expo install expo@^53.0.0 && npx @bycedric/expo-install --fix


ðŸ› ï¸ Resolve Dependency Conflicts

Create an .npmrc file to allow legacy peer dependencies:

echo
 
"legacy-peer-deps=true"
 
>> 
.npmrc


This helps bypass strict dependency resolution that can cause build failures.


ðŸ§¹ Clear Cached Files

Sometimes cached modules can cause unexpected behavior. Try removing them:

rm package-lock.json

rm
 
-rf 
node_modules/


Then reinstall:

npm install

ðŸŒ Environment-Specific Dependencies

Some Expo packages include native modules that donâ€™t work in web environments.
When using Bolt, make sure the ai understands which dependencies are platform-specific.
You can guide it by explicitly stating the target environment (iOS vs. web) when generating or editing code.


ðŸ“± Use Expo Go for Quick Testing

If you havenâ€™t already, try testing your app using Expo Go â€” itâ€™s a fast way to preview your app on a real device without a full build.

If these steps donâ€™t resolve the issue, feel free to send over your package.json and any recent changes you made before the crash started.
Weâ€™ll dig deeper and help get you back on track.

Weâ€™d love to see you back on the platform, and weâ€™re here to support you however we can.
name: Expo Fixes

text:
Keep files lean: If any files are hundreds or thousands of lines long, ask Bolt to split them into smaller components. This helps reduce context bloat and improves AI accuracy.

Use Selector Mode + Discussion Mode together: Selector Mode (mouse arrow icon at the top right of the preview window) helps Bolt focus on specific UI elements, while Discussion Mode gives you more control over prompt flow.

Check this guide: Troubleshooting prompt size issuesÂ , it covers best practices for managing large projects and avoiding context overflow.
name: Sizing

text:
{snippet name="@@HI"}

Thanks for reaching out, and I appreciate you letting us know about your subscription change.

Your {argument name="Current Plan"} plan is set to cancel on {argument name="Cycle end date"}. Until that date, your subscription remains active and youâ€™ll continue to have access to your current token balance.

Once the cancellation takes effect (on or shortly after {argument name="Cycle end date"}), youâ€™ll be able to upgrade to the {argument name="NewPlan"} plan directly at: â†’ https://bolt.new/pricing

Please note that I canâ€™t select the new plan on your behalf. 
Youâ€™ll need to complete the upgrade yourself through the pricing page. 
Any valid remaining tokens from your previous cycle will automatically roll over, so you wonâ€™t lose anything.

For more details on how token rollover works and how to manage your subscription, hereâ€™s a helpful guide: â†’ https://support.bolt.new/account-and-subscription/tokens

If you run into any issues during checkout or need help choosing the right plan, just let me know and Iâ€™ll be glad to assist.

{snippet name="@@bye"}
